bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Carlos E. Finlay, August 26, 1940

div1.p: Hench requests permission to see a copy of Finlay's biography of his father. Hench inquires about Carlos J. Finlay's activities and papers.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Carlos E. Finlay, August 26, 1940
div1.opener:
Copy to Mr Phillips (to show Moran)
sent him snapshot of himself & grandson.
3/6/41 - Sent hand letter,
Me Post, come etc
August 26, 1940
Dr. Carlos E. Finlay
25 #1057
Havana, Cuba
My dear Doctor Finlay:
div1.p:
You will remember that I visited Havana in April, in preparation for
an address which I have been asked to make at the dedication of the Lazear Memorial on
October 26, in Washington, Pennsylvania. You were very kind, indeed, to meet Mr. Moran and
me and to show us some of the souvenirs of your father's work. You will remember also that
Mr. Moran and I believe that Camp Lazear has been falsely located, and I have been collecting
documentary evidence to show that the camp was on the San Jose farm of Senora Maria Teresa
Loma viuda de Rojas. His Excellency, Dr. Ramos, has asked me to submit my data to him.
In preparation for this report, and also my address, I would appreciate it greatly if you
could give me a little information.

I believe that you admitted to Mr. Moran and to me that you did not
think that Camp Lazear as now marked was ever the real camp. I shall appreciate it greatly
if you would tell me why you think so. Did your father ever tell you about visiting the
camp and where it was? I believe that the place they have marked as “Camp Lazear” is
where they brought the victims of experimental yellow fever, and cared for them in a special
tent hospital in the rear of Columbia Barracks.

I was most interested to know of the manuscript which you were pub-
lishing about the life of your father. You told me it would be published this Fall in New
York, and I will most certainly buy a copy. But I am afraid this material will not be
available for the preparation of my address at Washington. You said that you had an extra
copy of your manuscript which I might borrow. I am most anxious to present to the American
audience the view that I learned in Cuba andas to the extent of your father's work. It is
the American view that your father was entirely correct in his theory but unable to produce
a single case of experimental yellow fever within the limits later learned to be necessary
for inoculation and incubation. Would you be willing to trust this manuscript to the mails,
sending it to me by registered insured post? I can assure you that I will take care of it
most carefully and return it to you as promptly as I can, also by registered insured mail.

One more question: Do you know the exact date in August, 1900, when
Major Reed called on your father for the larvae and his reprints? Do you know just which
members of the Commission called on him, I believe it was the first week of August, 1900?
Did your father have any letters or diaries that might give interesting and important in-
formation as to his contributions to Dr. Reed?

Permit me to express to you my deep appreciation of whatever help you
can give me in this matter. To save you the labor of answering this letter in long hand,
if your secretary is too busy to handle the matter, would you permit me to ask Mrs. R. Hart
Phillips, Manzana de Gomez, 553, who does secretarial work, to make an appointment at your
convenience and take down your answers, submitting her material to you for your correction
and signature. I shall be delighted to pay her charges.
div1.closer: Very sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
